feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued June 14 at 1:45AM AKDT until June 15 at 4:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM AKDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...High Surf expected. Strong southwesterly winds with gusts to 40 mph will create heavy wave action and will push the water levels 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tide line. * WHERE...Southern Seward Peninsula Coast.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued June 14 at 1:45AM AKDT until June 15 at 4:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM AKDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...High Surf expected. Strong southwesterly winds with gusts to 50 mph will create heavy wave action and will push the water levels 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tide line. * WHERE...Bering Strait Coast.
entry.cap:areaDesc: St Lawrence Island and Bering Strait Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 13 at 1:46PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water Levels Expected This Week... Heavy rain is occuring over the northeast Brooks Range east of the Dalton Highway. Rainfall totals from 1 to 1.5 inches are possible between Monday evening and Wednesday. Runoff from this rainfall and melting of the remaining snowpack will cause rivers draining the northeast Brooks Range to rise to bankfull levels in
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast; Northeastern Brooks Range

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 13 at 1:40PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water On The Koyukuk River This Week... Runoff from heavy rain in the Brooks Range late last week is moving down the Koyukuk River. The crest of high water is expected to reach Huslia from Wednesday into Thursday. This high water will cause erosion of the Koyukuk River bank at Huslia. Residents should prepare for significant erosion of the riverbank and high
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Koyukuk and Middle Yukon Valleys

entry.summary: ...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...Rivers draining the Brooks Range east of the Dalton Highway. * WHEN...Through Wednesday evening.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 14 at 9:28AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of central Barbour County through 1000 AM CDT... At 927 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Texasville, or 12 miles northeast of Clio, moving east at 25 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 14 at 9:10AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southwestern Colbert and northwestern Franklin Counties through 1000 AM CDT... At 910 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7 miles southwest of Burton, or 8 miles southeast of Booneville, moving east at 30 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 14 at 7:46AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Training thunderstorms are moving across much of Lee County this morning. This is creating ponding of water on roadways and low lying areas. Use caution while driving this morning. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 945 AM CDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 14 at 7:11AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1015 AM CDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of central Alabama, including the following county, Tallapoosa. * WHEN...Until 1015 AM CDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued June 14 at 2:34AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms are forecast through Thursday evening, mainly for areas along and south of Interstate 20. Thunderstorm activity will produce locally heavy rainfall, with the potential for repeated heavy rains over the same areas. As a result, 2 to 5 inches of rain is possible through Thursday evening, with locally higher amounts possible.

entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southeastern Hempstead, central Miller, northeastern Lafayette and southeastern Bowie Counties through 1000 AM CDT... entry.summary: ...Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of southeastern Madison and northeastern Franklin Counties through 945 AM CDT... entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 14 at 8:34AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON CDT THURSDAY... The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources has issued an Air Quality Advisory for PM2.5 which will remain in effect until noon Thursday. This advisory affects people living in the following counties: Adams, Buffalo, Clark, Jackson, Juneau, La Crosse, Monroe, Taylor, and Trempealeau counties
entry.cap:areaDesc: Adams; Buffalo; Clark; Jackson; Juneau; La Crosse; Monroe; Taylor; Trempealeau

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 13 at 10:03AM MDT until June 17 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Wyoming... Green River near La Barge affecting Lincoln and Sublette Counties. Bear River below Pixley Dam affecting Lincoln County. For the Green River Basin...including Big Piney, La Barge...elevated river levels are forecast.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 13 at 8:18AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Several days of heavy rainfall in western Hot Springs County has caused flows to increase on Owl Creek. Additionally, releases from Anchor Dam will be increased today to mitigate concerns in that area. Flows in Owl Creek are expected to be bankfull and higher to cause minor flooding concerns from Anchor Dam down to the Bighorn River.
